column1: Palm Springs is a desert resort city in Riverside County
column2: California
column3: United States
column4: within the Colorado Desert's Coachella Valley. The city covers approximately 94 square miles (240 km2)
column5: making it the largest city in Riverside County by land area. With multiple plots in checkerboard pattern
column6: more than 10% of the city is part of the Agua Caliente Band of Cahuilla Indians reservation land. Traditionally the Cahuilla refer to the Palm Springs area as Pal Séxey
column7: or Séx'i.Although the population of Palm Springs was 44
column8: 552 as of the 2010 census
column9: because Palm Springs is a retirement location
column10: as well as a winter snowbird destination
column11: the city's population triples between November and March.The city is noted for its mid-century modern architecture

column1: The first humans to settle in the area were the Cahuilla people
column2: who arrived 2
column3: 000 years ago. Cahuilla Indians lived here in isolation from other cultures for hundreds of years prior to European contact. They spoke Ivilyuat
column4: which is a Uto-Aztecan language. Numerous prominent and powerful Cahuilla leaders were from Palm Springs
column5: including Cahuilla Lion (Chief Juan Antonio). While Palm Canyon was occupied during winter months
column6: they often moved to cooler Chino Canyon during the summer months.The Cahuilla Indians had several permanent settlements in the canyons of Palm Springs
column7: due to the abundance of water and shade. Various hot springs were used during wintertime. The Cahuilla hunted rabbit
column8: mountain goat and quail
column9: while also trapping fish in nearby lakes and rivers. While men were responsible for hunting
column10: women were responsible for collecting berries
column11: acorns and seeds. They also made tortillas from mesquite beans. While the Cahuillas often spent the summers in Indian Canyons
column12: the current site of Spa Resort Casino in downtown was often used during winter due to its natural hot springs.Native American petroglyphs can be seen in Tahquitz
column14: and Indian Canyons. The Cahuilla's irrigation ditches
column15: dams and house pits can also be seen here. Ancient petroglyphs
column16: pictographs and mortar holes can be seen in Andreas Canyon. The mortar holes were used to grind acorns into meals.The Agua Caliente ("Hot Water") Reservation was established in 1876 and consists of 31
column17: 128 acres. Six thousand seven hundred acres are located by Downtown Palm Springs. The Native American land is on long lease land and next to one of California's high-end communities
column18: making the tribe one of the wealthiest in California.The first name for Palm Springs was given by the native Cahuilla: "Se-Khi" (boiling water). When the Agua Caliente Reservation was established by the United States government in 1876
column19: the reservation land was composed of alternating sections (640 acres) of land laid out across the desert in a checkerboard pattern. The alternating non-reservation sections were granted to the Southern Pacific Railroad as an incentive to bring rail lines through the Sonoran Desert.

column13: 700 ha) lie within the city limits
column14: making the Agua Caliente natives the city's largest landowners. (Tribal enrollment as of 2010 was 410 people.)

column1: As of 1821 Mexico was independent of Spain and in March 1823 the Mexican Monarchy ended. That same year (in December) Mexican diarist José María Estudillo and Brevet Captain José Romero were sent to find a route from Sonora to Alta California; on their expedition they first recorded the existence of "Agua Caliente" at Palm Springs
column2: California. With the Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo after the Mexican-American war
column3: the region became part of the United States in 1848.

column1: One possible origin of palm in the place name comes from early Spanish explorers who referred to the area as La Palma de la Mano de Dios or "The Palm of God's hand". The earliest use of the name "Palm Springs" is from United States Topographical Engineers who used the term in 1853 maps. According to William Bright
column2: when the word "palm" appears in Californian place names
column3: it usually refers to the native California fan palm
column4: Washingtonia filifera
column5: which is abundant in the Palm Springs area. Other early names were "Palmetto Spring" and "Big Palm Springs".The first European resident in Palm Springs itself was Jack Summers
column6: who ran the stagecoach station on the Bradshaw Trail in 1862. Fourteen years later (1876)
column7: the Southern Pacific railroad was laid 6 miles to the north
column8: isolating the station. In 1880
column9: local Indian Pedro Chino was selling parcels near the springs to William Van Slyke and Mathew Bryne in a series of questionable transactions; they in turn brought in W. R. Porter to help market their property through the "Palm City Land and Water Company". By 1885
column10: when San Francisco attorney (later known as "Judge") John Guthrie McCallum began buying property in Palm Springs
column11: the name was already in wide acceptance. The area was named "Palm Valley" when McCallum incorporated the "Palm Valley Land and Water Company" with partners O.C. Miller

column2: who had brought his ill son to the dry climate for health
column3: brought in irrigation advocate Dr. Oliver Wozencroft and engineer J. P. Lippincott to help construct a canal from the Whitewater River to fruit orchards on his property. He also asked Dr. Welwood Murray to establish a hotel across the street from his residence. Murray did so in 1886 (he later became a famous horticulturalist). The crops and irrigation systems suffered flooding in 1893 from record rainfall
column4: and then an 11-year drought (1894–1905) caused further damage.

column1: The city became a fashionable resort in the 1900s when health tourists arrived with conditions that required dry heat. Because of the heat
column2: however
column3: the population dropped markedly in the summer months.  In 1906 naturalist and travel writer George Wharton James's two volume The Wonders of the Colorado Desert described Palm Springs as having "great charms and attractiveness" and included an account of his stay at Murray's hotel. As James also described
column4: Palm Springs was more comfortable in its microclimate because the area was covered in the shadow of Mount San Jacinto to the west and in the winter the mountains block cold winds from the San Gorgonio pass. Early illustrious visitors included John Muir and his daughters
column5: U.S. Vice President Charles Fairbanks
column6: and Fanny Stevenson
column7: widow of Robert Louis Stevenson; still
column8: Murray's hotel was closed in 1909 and torn down in 1954.Nellie N. Coffman and her physician husband Harry established The Desert Inn as a hotel and sanitarium in 1909. It was expanded as a modern hotel in 1927 and continued on until 1967. Coffman herself was a "driving force" in the city's tourism industry until her death in 1950.

column1: James's Wonders of the Colorado Desert (above) was followed in 1920 by J. Smeaton Chase's Our Araby: Palm Springs and the Garden of the Sun
column2: which also  promoted the area. In 1924 Pearl McCallum (daughter of Judge McCallum) returned to Palm Springs and built the Oasis Hotel with her husband Austin G. McManus; the Modern/Art Deco resort was designed by Lloyd Wright and featured a 40-foot tower. The next major hotel was the El Mirador
column3: a large and luxurious resort that attracted the biggest movie stars; opening in 1927
column4: its prominent feature was a 68-foot tall Renaissance style tower. Silent film star Fritzi Ridgeway's 100-room Hotel del Tahquitz was built in 1929
column5: next to the "Fool's Folly" mansion built by Chicago heiress Lois Kellogg. Golfing was available at the O'Donnell 9 hole course (1926) and the El Mirador (1929) course (see Golf below). Hollywood movie stars were attracted by the hot dry
column6: sunny weather and seclusion – they built homes and estates in the Warm Sands
column8: and Historic Tennis Club neighborhoods (see Neighborhoods below). About 20
column9: 000 visitors came to the area in 1922.Palm Springs became popular with movie stars in the 1930s and estate building expanded into the Movie Colony neighborhoods
column11: and Las Palmas neighborhoods. Actors Charles Farrell and Ralph Bellamy opened the Racquet Club in 1934 and Pearl McCallum opened the Tennis Club in 1937. Nightclubs were set up as well
column12: with Al Wertheimer opening The Dunes outside of Palm Springs in 1934 and the Chi Chi nightclub opening in 1936. Besides the gambling available at the Dunes Club
column13: other casinos included The 139 Club and The Cove Club outside of the city.

column1: When the United States entered World War II
column2: Palm Springs and the Coachella Valley were important in the war effort. The original airfield near Palm Springs became a staging area for the Air Corps Ferrying Command's 21st Ferrying Group in November 1941 and a new airfield was built ½ mile from the old site. The new airfield
column3: designated Palm Springs Army Airfield
column4: was completed in early 1942. Personnel from the Air Transport Command 560th Army Air Forces Base Unit stayed at the La Paz Guest Ranch and training was conducted at the airfield by the 72nd and 73rd Ferrying Squadrons. Later training was provided by the IV Fighter Command 459th Base Headquarters and Air Base Squadron.

column1: Eight months before Pearl Harbor Day
column2: the El Mirador Hotel was fully booked and adding new facilities. After the war started
column3: the U.S. government bought the hotel from owner Warren Phinney for $750
column5: just over $13
column8: and converted it into the Torney General Hospital
column9: with Italian prisoners of war serving as kitchen help and orderlies in 1944 and 1945. Through the war it was staffed with 1
column11: 000 patients.General Patton's Desert Training Center encompassed the entire region
column12: with its headquarters in Camp Young at the Chiriaco Summit and an equipment depot maintained by the 66th Ordnance in present-day Palm Desert.

column1: Architectural modernists flourished with commissions from the stars
column2: using the city to explore architectural innovations
column3: new artistic venues
column4: and an exotic back-to-the-land experiences. Inventive architects designed unique vacation houses
column5: such as steel houses with prefabricated panels and folding roofs
column6: a glass-and-steel house in a boulder-strewn landscape
column7: and a carousel house that turned to avoid the sun's glare.In 1946
column8: Richard Neutra designed the Edgar and Liliane Kaufmann House. A modernist classic
column9: this mostly glass residence incorporated the latest technological advances in building materials
column10: using natural lighting and floating planes and flowing space for proportion and detail. In recent years an energetic preservation program has protected and enhanced many classic buildings.

column1: Culver (2010) argues that Palm Springs architecture became the model for mass-produced suburban housing
column2: especially in the Southwest. This "Desert Modern" style was a high-end architectural style featuring open-design plans
column3: wall-to-wall carpeting
column4: air-conditioning
column5: swimming pools
column6: and very large windows. As Culver concludes
column8: the masses would not. Here
column9: it seemed
column10: were houses that fully merged inside and outside
column11: providing spaces for that essential component of Californian—and indeed middle-class American—life: leisure. While not everyone could have a Neutra masterpiece
column12: many families could adopt aspects of Palm Springs modern."

column1: Hollywood values permeated the resort as it combined celebrity
column2: health
column3: new wealth
column4: and sex. As Culver (2010) explains: "The bohemian sexual and marital mores already apparent in Hollywood intersected with the resort atmosphere of Palm Springs
column5: and this new
column6: more open sexuality would gradually appear elsewhere in national tourist culture." During this period
column8: stimulated by real estate developers systematically removed and excluded poor people and Indians.Palm Springs was pictured by the French photographer Robert Doisneau in November 1960 as part of an assignment for Fortune on the construction of golf courses in this particularly dry and hot area of the Colorado desert. Doisneau submitted around 300 slides following his ten-day stay depicting the lifestyle of wealthy retirees and Hollywood stars in the 1960s. At the time

column2: Palm Springs remained popular with the rich and famous of Hollywood
column3: as well as retirees and Canadian tourists. Between 1947 and 1965
column4: the Alexander Construction Company built some 2
column5: 200 houses in Palm Springs effectively doubling its housing capacity.

column1: As the 1970s drew to a close
column2: increasing numbers of retirees moved to the Coachella Valley. As a result
column3: Palm Springs began to evolve from a virtual ghost town in the summer to a year-round community. Businesses and hotels that used to close for the months of July and August instead remained open all summer. As commerce grew
column4: so too did the number of families with children.

column1: The recession of 1973–1975 affected Palm Springs as many of the wealthy residents had to cut back on their spending. Later in the 1970s numerous Chicago mobsters invested $50 million in the Palm Springs area
column2: buying houses
column3: land
column4: and businesses. While Palm Springs faced competition from the desert cities to the east in the later 1980s
column5: it has continued to prosper into the 21st century.

column1: Since the early 1950s the city had been a popular spring break resort. Glamorized as a destination in the 1963 movie Palm Springs Weekend
column2: the number of visitors grew and at times the gatherings had problems. In 1969 an estimated 15
column3: 000 people had gathered for a concert at the Palm Springs Angel Stadium and 300 were arrested for drunkenness or disturbing the peace. In the 1980s 10
column4: 000+ college students would visit the city and form crowds and parties – and another rampage occurred in 1986 when Palm Springs Police in riot gear had to put down the rowdy crowd. In 1990
column5: due to complaints by residents
column6: mayor Sonny Bono and the city council closed the city's Palm Canyon Drive to Spring Breakers and the downtown businesses lost money normally filled by the tourists.

column1: Tourism is a major factor in the city's economy with 1.6 million visitors in 2011. The city has over 130 hotels and resorts
column2: numerous bed and breakfasts
column3: and over 100 restaurants and dining spots. Events such as the Coachella and Stagecoach Festivals in nearby Indio attracting younger people
column4: making greater Palm Springs a more attractive area to retire.Following the 2008 recession Palm Springs revitalized its Downtown
column5: "the Village". Rebuilding started with the demolition of the Bank of America building in January 2012
column6: with the Desert Fashion Plaza scheduled for demolition in 2013.The movement behind Mid-Century modern architecture (1950s/60s era) in Palm Springs is backed by architecture enthusiasts
column7: artistic designers and local historians to preserve many of Central Palm Springs' buildings and houses of famous celebrities
column8: businessmen and politicians.

column1: Palm Springs is located in the Sonoran Desert. According to the United States Census Bureau
column2: the city has a total area of 95.0 square miles (246 km2)
column3: of which 94.1 square miles (244 km2) is land and 0.9 square miles (2.3 km2) (1%) is water. Located in the Coachella Valley desert region
column4: Palm Springs is sheltered by the San Bernardino Mountains to the north
column5: the Santa Rosa Mountains to the south
column6: by the San Jacinto Mountains to the west and by the Little San Bernardino Mountains to the east.

column1: Palm Springs has a hot desert climate
column2: with over 300 days of sunshine and 4.93 inches (125.2 mm) of precipitation annually. The winter months are warm
column3: with a majority of days reaching 70 °F (21 °C) and in January and February days often see temperatures of 80 °F (27 °C) and on occasion reach over 90 °F (32 °C)
column4: while
column5: on average
column6: there are 17 nights annually dipping to or below 40 °F (4 °C); freezing temperatures occur in less than half of years. The lowest temperature recorded is 19 °F (−7 °C)
column8: 1937.Summers are extremely hot
column9: with daytime temperatures consistently surpassing 110 °F (43 °C) while overnight temperatures often remain above 80 °F (27 °C). The mean annual temperature is 74.7 °F (23.7 °C). There are 180 days with a high reaching 90 °F (32 °C)
column10: and 100 °F (38 °C) can be seen on 116 days. The highest temperature on record in Palm Springs is 123 °F (51 °C)
column11: most recently achieved on July 28 and 29
column12: 1995. The climate year-round is suitable for many palm trees in this area of California due to the amount of sunny days annually

column1: The locale features a variety of native Low Desert flora and fauna. A notable tree occurring in the wild and under cultivation is the California Fan Palm
column2: Washingtonia filifera.

column1: The City of Palm Springs has developed a program to identify distinctive neighborhoods in the community. Of the 45 neighborhoods
column2: 7 have historical and cultural significance.

column1: The Movie Colony is just east of Palm Canyon Drive. The Movie Colony East neighborhood extends further east from the Ruth Hardy Park. These areas started growing in the 1930s as Hollywood movie stars built their smaller getaways from their Los Angeles area estates. Bob Hope
column2: Frank Sinatra
column3: Estée Lauder
column4: Carmen Miranda and Bing Crosby built homes in these neighborhoods.

column2: Robert Fey built 70 homes designed by Donald Wexler and Ric Harrison in the El Rancho Vista Estates. Noted residents included Jack LaLanne and comic Andy Dick.

column1: Historic homes in the Warm Sands area date from the 1920s and many were built from adobe. It also includes small resorts and the Ramon Mobile Home Park. Noted residents have included screenwriter Walter Koch
column2: artist Paul Grimm
column3: activist Cleve Jones and actor Wesley Eure.

column1: The Mesa started off as a gated community developed in the 1920s near the Indian Canyons. Noted residents have included King Gillette
column2: Zane Grey
column3: Clark Gable
column4: Carole Lombard
column5: Suzanne Somers
column6: Herman Wouk
column8: Barry Manilow and Trina Turk. Distinctive homes include Donald Wexler's "butterfly houses" and the "Streamline Moderne Ship of the Desert".

column1: Some of the homes in this neighborhood date from the 1930s. The area was owned by Pearl McCallum McManus and she started building homes in the neighborhood after World War II ended. Dr. William Scholl (Dr. Scholl's foot products) owned a 10-acre estate here. Today the neighborhood is the largest neighborhood organization with 600 homes and businesses within its boundaries.

column2: the original Sunmor Estates area was the western portion the Palm Springs Army Airfield. Homes here were developed by Robert Higgins and the Alexander Construction Company. Actor and former mayor Frank Bogert bought his home for $16
column3: 000 and lived there for more than 50 years.

column1: Palm Springs has one of the highest concentrations of same-sex couples of any community in the United States. In 2010
column3: 307) of the city's households belong to  same-sex married couples or partnerships
column4: compared to the national average of 1%. Palm Springs has the fifth-highest percentage of same-sex households in the nation. Former mayor Ron Oden estimated that about a third of Palm Springs is gay. Over various times
column5: the city has catered to LGBT tourists with an increasing number of clothing-optional resorts and events. Palm Springs is host to the Greater Palm Springs Pride Celebration. This celebration
column6: held every year in November
column7: includes events such as the Palm Springs Pride Golf Classic
column8: the Stonewall Equality Concert
column9: and a Broadway in Drag Pageant. The city also held same-sex wedding ceremonies at the iconic Forever Marilyn statue located downtown
column10: before its relocation in 2014. In January 2018
column11: Palm Springs ushered in America's first all-LGBTQ city government.

column1: Though celebrities still retreat to Palm Springs
column2: many today establish residences in other areas of the Coachella Valley. The city's economy now relies on tourism
column3: and local government is largely supported by related retail sales taxes and the TOT (transient occupancy tax). It is a city of numerous festivals
column4: conventions
column5: and international events including the Palm Springs International Film Festival.

column1: The world's largest rotating aerial tramcars (cable cars) can be found at the Palm Springs Aerial Tramway. These cars
column2: built by Von Roll Tramways
column3: ascend from Chino Canyon two-and-a-half miles up a steep incline to the station at 8
column4: 516 feet (2
column5: 596 m). The San Jacinto Wilderness is accessible from the top of the tram and there is a restaurant with notable views.

column1: Palm Springs Annual Homecoming Parade is held on the Wednesday prior to the Friday night Palm Springs High School Homecoming Game.
The city sponsors a Veterans Day parade
column2: concert and fireworks display since 1996. It is one of 54 US Department of Veterans Affairs designated Regional Sites for the national observance of Veterans Day.

column1: The city and various individuals have sponsored different public art projects in the city.Numerous galleries and studios are located in the city and region. The California Art Club has a chapter in Palm Springs. The Desert Art Center of Coachella Valley was established in Palm Springs in 1950.

column1: Palm Springs is home to the Palm Springs POWER
column2: a semi-pro collegiate league baseball team composed of college all-stars of the Southern California Collegiate Baseball Association. It has a winter league baseball team
column3: the POWER winter team and Palm Springs Chill of the California Winter League (2010) consists of 12 other teams as of 2016. The League plays its games in Palm Springs Stadium and also on the baseball field in nearby Palm Springs High School. Both sites feature 6 teams of the Palm Springs Collegiate League in the summer.The Palm Springs stadium was once the spring training site of the Major League Baseball California Angels (now the Los Angeles Angels) of the American League from 1961 to 1993. The stadium also hosted spring training of the Chicago White Sox  in the late 1940s-1950s
column4: the Oakland A's in the 1970s
column5: and the 1950s minor league Seattle Rainiers of the Pacific Coast League also trained there.

column2: Palm Springs was approved to become the home to an expansion team in the American Hockey League announced to begin play in the 2022–23 season. The team is the affiliate of the Seattle Kraken and will play in a privately funded arena  in nearby Palm Desert
column3: California.

column1: The Palm Springs area features numerous major sports events
column2: including the annual BNP Paribas Open in March
column3: voted by professional players over several years in the early 21st century as the premier mandatory Tournament of the Year. The Easter Bowl
column4: sponsored by the United States Tennis Association is a showcase tournament for junior tennis players (girls and boys aged 12 to 18 years) held annually in March among several tennis centers of the Palm Springs area.

column1: With more golf courses than any other region in California
column2: Coachella Valley is the most popular golf vacation destination in California. Early golf courses in Palm Springs were the O'Donnell Golf Club (built by oil magnate Thomas A. O'Donnell) and the El Mirador Hotel course
column3: both of which opened in the 1920s. After the Cochran-Odlum (Indio) and Shadow Mountain pitch and putt courses were built after World II
column4: the first 18-hole golf course in the area was the Thunderbird Country Club
column5: established 1951 in Rancho Mirage. Thunderbird was designed by golf course architects Lawrence Hughes and Johnny Dawson and in 1955 it hosted the 11th Ryder Cup championship.

column1: In the 1970s the area had over 40 courses and in 2001 the 100th course was opened. The area is also home to the PGA Tour's Humana Challenge in partnership with the Clinton Foundation (formerly the Bob Hope Chrysler Classic)
column2: the LPGA's ANA Inspiration and the Canadian Tour's Desert Dunes Classic.

column1: The Palm Springs AYSO Region 80 plays in Section 1H of the American Youth Soccer Organization.
The Palm Springs Desert Ice Palace ice skating rink opened in nearby Cathedral City in October 2011.
Boomers! is a family entertainment center in Cathedral City.
A city skatepark was designed after the noted Nude Bowl.

CNL Financial Group operates the Wet'n'Wild Palm Springs water park in the summer. (Formerly operated as Knott's Soak City by Cedar Fair Entertainment Company.)In 1931 the Desert Riders was established. Starting off as a social organization for the cream of Palm Springs society
column2: the group sponsors horseback riding and trail building for equestrians
column3: hikers
column4: and bicyclists. The Desert Riders were also significant in providing combination chuckwagon meals and rides through nearby canyons to hotel guests as Palm Springs developed its tourist industry.

column1: Business owners in the village first established a Palm Springs Board of Trade in 1918
column2: followed by a chamber of commerce; the city itself was established by election in 1938 and converted to a charter city
column3: with a charter adopted by the voters in 1994.Presently the city has a council-manager type government
column4: with a five-person city council that hires a city manager and city attorney. The mayor is directly elected and serves a four-year term. The other four council members also serve four-year terms
column5: with staggered elections. The city is considered a full-service city
column6: in that it staffs and manages its own police and fire departments including parks and recreation programs
column8: sewer system and wastewater treatment plant
column9: international airport

column1: The city government is a member of the Southern California Association of Governments.The current mayor is Geoff Kors
column2: who took office in December
column3: 2019. Kors is the City's fourth openly gay mayor in the city's history. Palm Springs' longest-tenured mayor was Frank Bogert (1958–66 and 1982–88)
column4: but the best-known mayor was Sonny Bono. Bono served from 1988 to 1992 and was eventually elected to the U.S. Congress.

column1: Public education in Palm Springs is under the jurisdiction of the Palm Springs Unified School District
column2: an independent district with five board members. The Palm Springs High School is the oldest school in the district
column3: built in 1938. Originally it was a K–12 school in the 1920s and had the College of the Desert campus from 1958 to 1964. And Raymond Cree Middle School in its current site since the mid 1960s.

column1: Palm Springs is the 144th largest TV market as defined by AC Nielsen. The Palm Springs DMA is unique among TV markets as it is entirely located within only a small portion of Riverside County. Also
column2: while most areas received their first local television stations during the 1950s
column3: Palm Springs did not receive its first TV stations until October 1968 when stations KPLM-TV (now KESQ) and KMIR-TV debuted. Prior to that time
column4: Palm Springs was served by TV stations from the Los Angeles market
column5: which were carried on the local cable system that began operations in the 1950s and which predated the emergence of local broadcast stations by more than a decade.

column1: The city's library was started in 1924 and financed by Martha Hitchcock. It expanded in 1940 on land donated to the newly incorporated city by Dr. Welwood Murray and was financed through the efforts of Thomas O'Donnell. The present site now operates as a branch library

column3: and tourism office for the Palm Springs Bureau of Tourism.

column1: One of the first transportation routes for Palm Springs was on the Bradshaw Trail
column2: an historic overland stage coach route from San Bernardino to La Paz
column3: Arizona. The Bradshaw Trail operated from 1862 to 1877. In the 1870s the Southern Pacific Railroad expanded its lines into the Coachella Valley.Modern transportation services include:

column1: Palm Springs International Airport serves Palm Springs and the Coachella Valley.
Historical note: during World War II it was operated as the Palm Springs Army Airfield.

Amtrak's Sunset Limited and Texas Eagle form a single train which stops thrice weekly at the Palm Springs Amtrak station.
Amtrak's Thruway Motorcoach connects Palm Springs to Bakersfield

column1: SR 62 – California State Route 62 (a Blue Star Memorial Highway) intersects I-10 northwest of the city and runs north to San Bernardino County and the Colorado River.

column2: the Jane Augustine Patencio Cemetery was established on Tahquitz Way with the burial of Jane Augustine Patencio. It is maintained by the Agua Caliente Tribe.

column1: The Welwood Murray Cemetery was started by hotel operator Welwood Murray in 1894 when his son died. It is maintained by the Palm Springs Cemetery District

column1: The fauna of Palm Springs is mostly species adapted to desert
column2: temperature extremes and to lack of moisture. It is located within the Nearctic faunistic realm in a region containing an assemblage of species similar to Northern Africa. Native fauna includes pronghorns
column3: desert bighorn sheep
column4: desert tortoise
column5: kit fox
column6: desert iguanas
column8: chuckwalla
column9: bobcats
column10: mountain lions and Gila monsters. Other animals include ground squirrels
column16: pocket gophers and raccoons. Desert birds here include the iconic roadrunner
column17: which can run at speeds exceeding 15 mp/h. Other avifauna includes the ladder-backed woodpecker
column21: sparrow hawks and a variety of raptors.The Sonoran Desert has more species of rattlesnakes (11) than anywhere else in the world. The most common species is the extremely venomous Mojave rattler
column22: which is considered the world's most dangerous rattlesnake. The largest rattle snake species here is the western diamondback rattlesnake
column23: while other species include the black-tailed rattlesnake
column24: tiger rattler and sidewinder rattler. Palm Springs is home to tarantulas and various scorpion species
column25: including the vinegaroon.Although black bears are not common in the Coachella Valley
column26: bears have been observed in Palm Springs and other parts of California.Today
column27: jaguars roam the northern Mexican dry-lands; however
column28: they were previously common throughout the Coachella Valley. The last documented jaguar sighting in Palm Springs
